questions.text: 200 people attended a party and some of them had diarrhea after 24 hours. They ate oyster, hamburger, ice cream, and potato salad. What’s the likely cause? 40 ill from 50 who consumed oyster 50 ill from 135 who consumed hamburger 60 ill from 140 who consumed salad 49 ill from 115 who consumed ice cream
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vibrio parahaemolyticus IN THIS QUES, Most guests who ate the oysters, that's why the most likely source of infection is by Vibrio parahaemolyticus. V. parahaemolyticus is a capsulated vibrio with peritrichous flagella. Infections with V. parahaemolyticus can result in two distinct gastrointestinal presentations (including nearly all cases in North America). The most common presentation is watery diarrhea, usually occurring in conjunction with abdominal cramps, nausea, and vomiting and accompanied in 25% of cases by fever and chills. Dysentery, the less common presentation, is characterized by severe abdominal cramps, nausea, vomiting, and bloody or mucoid stools. V. parahaemolyticus contains two type III secretion systems, which directly inject toxic bacterial proteins into host cells. After an incubation period of 4 hours to 4 days, symptoms develop and persist for a median of 3 days. V. parahaemolyticus is linked to its ability to cause hemolysis on Wagatsuma agar), i.e., is called Kanagawa phenomenon. Doxycycline, fluoroquinolones, or macrolides are preferred in this case. questions.text: A postrenal transplant patient presents with diarrhea after 3 months. It showed organisms measuring 2-6-micron meter and Kinyoun stain positive. Most likely it is caused by:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cryptosporidium parvum Opportunistic infections are extremely common post-transplant in the period starting from 1-month post-transplant to 6 months’ post-transplant. Clostridium difficile is usually seen within 1-month post-transplant because of profound antibiotic use. Kinyoun stain (modified acid fast) positivity rules out Balantidium. Now it is between cryptosporidium and cyclo Isospora. Size (smaller, i.e., 2–6 microns) tells us that the organism is undoubtedly Cryptosporidium parvum.

questions.text: A patient is having thick, gray coating on the throat and tonsils, followed by fever, chills, and swollen glands in the neck. Microscopic examination of nasopharyngeal or pharyngeal swab showed gram-positive organisms with a special stain. The constitutes of the stain are:

options.label: B
options.text: Toluidine blue, malachite green, glacial acetic

options.label: C
options.text: Carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, and methylene blue

questions.correct_answer: B. Toluidine blue, malachite green, glacial acetic
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Toluidine blue, malachite green, glacial acetic The clinical scenario depicts Corynebacterium diphtheriae infection. The special staining used for Corynebacterium diphtheriae is Albert’s. Albert’s solution is of two types A and B given below briefly: Albert’s A solution Albert’s B solution • Toluidine blue 0.15 g • Malachite green 0.20 g • Glacial acetic acid 1 mL • Alcohol (95% ethanol) 2 mL • Iodine 2 g • Potassium iodide (KI) 3 g Albert’s metachromatic stains kit (K002) Metachromatic Granules-Black Cytoplasm-Light green Note : Neisser’s stain and Ponder’s stain are also used to demonstrate polar bodies of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Highyeild:

Clinical features : Respiratory diphtheria Primary nasal diphtheria: It is more common in young children and infants. It is the mildest form of diphtheria. Diphtheria: It is the most common type of diphtheria which appears as area of yellow or dirty white exudate adjacent to tonsils which later join to form pseudomembrane on the mucous membranes of the pharynx, tonsils, and vulva. After few days the pseudomembrane changes to greyish color because of hemorrhage. Initially, the patient presents with sore throat and fever but in later stages dysphagia, headache and voice change can be seen. The enlargement of lymph node and soft tissue edema gives the appearance of “Bull neck.” Bull’s neck vs. Bull’s eye Bull’s neck: Seen in tonsillopharyngeal diphtheria. Bull’s eye retinopathy: Adverse effect of chloroquine. Laryngotracheal diphtheria : These patients have high chances of developing suffocation because of edema of soft tissue and dense cast of respiratory epithelium. Resection of pseudomembrane and establishment of artificial airway should be done. Cutaneous diphtheria : It is characterized by nothing but punched out ulcer with brown grey membrane. It is caused by nontoxigenic strains. Extremities are most commonly affected. Mucocutaneous sites like ear and genital tract are rarely affected. Complication of diphtheria : Airway obstruction by pseudomembrane is commonly seen. The orders of complications are: Airway obstruction > Toxic cardiomyopathy (Occurs during 2–3 week of illness) > Toxic neuropathy (10 days to 3 month) > Encephalitis. Most common complication of diphtheria is respiratory obstruction followed by death. Isolated peripheral nerve palsies or a symptom complex mimicking Guillain– Barre syndrome and degenerative changes in the nervous system can be seen. Pneumonia, renal failure, encephalitis, cerebral infarction, and pulmonary embolism also can be seen. Treatment Diphtheria antitoxin is administered empirically based on the estimated amount of toxin present. Penicillin G or erythromycin is generally given to render the patient noncontagious. Antibiotics do not affect the course of disease.

questions.text: A newly introduced vaccine includes all, except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Influenza Rota virus It has been approved by the Government of India for inclusion into the UIP with the phase I launch of the vaccine in 4 states (Himachal Pradesh, Odisha, Andhra Pradesh, and Haryana) in February 2016. It is administered at age 6–15 weeks. Maximum age for administering the last dose of either vaccine should be 32 weeks. Dengue vaccine It is known as Dengvaxia (CYD-TDV). It is live recombinant as a 3-dose series on a 0/6/12 months’ schedule in Phase II clinical studies. It has been registered for use in individuals 9–45 years of age living in endemic areas. In April 2016, WHO Strategic Advisory Group of Experts (SAGE) on immunization recommended introduction of the vaccine only in geographic settings (national or subnational) with endemicity. Malaria vaccine It is known as RTS, S/AS01 It is the first malaria vaccine to have completed Phase III testing. RTS, S is a vaccine against Plasmodium falciparum. It offers no protection against P. vivax malaria The vaccine is being considered as a complementary malaria control tool in Africa.
